blog.name: thetangential
blog.title: The Tangential
blog.description: A creative writing blog. Our mission: Don't be boring. Don't suck.

summary: With the 20th anniversary of The Phantom Menace coming up (surely you’re counting the days), Star Wars fans have been showing...
caption:
With the 20th anniversary of The Phantom Menace coming up (surely you’re counting the days), Star Wars fans have been showing their love for the characters who debuted in that first and most maligned of the franchise prequels. Lucasfilm has been fanning the flames with bonbons including a panel discussion at this year’s Celebration convention and books like Queen’s Shadow, which finally gives Padmé an entire story to herself with no interference from Anakin.

Anakin is also absent from Claudia Gray’s Master & Apprentice, although the Force rumbles with intimations of his birth. Distinguished as the earliest novel in the current Star Wars canon timeline, it’s a lavish exposition of Qui-Gon Jinn’s backstory: why he’s not on the Jedi Council despite his accomplished status, why he’s such a mystical rogue, what it was like to be Count Dooku’s Padawan. As the title promises, Gray also probes the complex and weirdly intimate relationships between teachers and students in the Jedi Order.

Speaking of weirdly intimate, Master & Apprentice may mark the first appearance of the phrase “gettin’ laid” in the Star Wars canon.

read the full review

title: On Writing Dialogue
body:
One of my favorite things to do when I’m rewatching movies and tv shows (such as we’re currently doing with Star Wars: Rebels) is to listen to the dialogue. When I watch something for the first time, I’m usually paying more attention to how the plot is unfolding than I am with what’s being said, so I may miss out on a few clues here and there. But that’s okay…the repeated watching is where I pay…

View On WordPress

tags: I'll go read it after i calm down
summary: I don't want to judge a comic before reading it myself, but it seems really strange that the narrative theme and message in...
body:
I don’t want to judge a comic before reading it myself, but it seems really strange that the narrative theme and message in “Dark Visions” #3 is that “women are foolish for having compassion for Darth Vader” but compassion is one of the major themes of Star Wars and Vader was explicitly saved because of his son’s compassion for him.

The whole point of Vader’s character is that beneath the masked monster there is a broken and sad man who needed compassion in order to reach redemption!

So why the fuck is this comic framing a woman as a deranged lunatic for having compassion for Vader???!?!?!

It’s antithetical to the themes of Star Wars, who the fuck greenlit this comic

So why the fuck is this comic framing a woman as a deranged lunatic for having compassion for Vader???!?!?!

blog.name: seaweedbrainswisegirl
blog.title: SAVE BEN SOLO
blog.description: Bendemption and Reylo kiss in TROS pleaaaaseeeee

summary:
"Unca Wanwo!"
"There's my little buddy!" Lando said, scooping the boy up in his arms and turning him upside down to giggles and...
body:
I can show you the ways of the capes

“Unca Wanwo!”

“There’s my little buddy!” Lando said, scooping the boy up in his arms and turning him upside down to giggles and shrieks.

“Always happy to see the young Mr. Ben.”

The Last Shot

Ahhhhhhhh young Ben Solo is my absolute favorite. I wonder what will be Kylo’s reaction when he meet his Uncle Lando in The Rise of Skywalker.

summary: It’s completely fine to remove Rey as the main protagonist and they claim it wouldn’t be bad writing to shift perspectives...
body:
I don’t know why I even still have Reddit

It’s completely fine to remove Rey as the main protagonist and they claim it wouldn’t be bad writing to shift perspectives RANDOMLY within the story. Kylo is great but that would legit burn the trilogy.

summary: Ciao! Penso tu abbia visto tutto il discorso su Dark Visions, definire quella storia offensiva è ben poco. Per curiosità sono...
question: Ciao! Penso tu abbia visto tutto il discorso su Dark Visions, definire quella storia offensiva è ben poco. Per curiosità sono andata a cercare l'autore su Twitter per vedere se avrebbe risposto alle critiche e invece cosa trovo? Solo lui che retwitta recensioni positive e di gente divertita, tra l'altro di quasi solo uomini. Perchè Lucasfilm ha fatto pubblicare una roba del genere?
answer:
Ciao!

Sì, purtroppo ho visto. Non ho approfondito ancora la vicenda ma, se non sbaglio, ho letto che originariamente la storia doveva essere sui “toxic fanboys”. Che questo sia stato cambiato in una ragazza è tremendo, perché dalla presa in giro si è passato in un attimo all'umiliazione. Alla mortificazione delle fangirls.

Sono rattristata e infastidita perché continuiamo a avere segnali contrastanti: come si fa a vendere alla celebration t-shirts con scritto “Star wars è per tutti” e poi pubblicare qualcosa di così offensivo per una buona fetta dei fans?

Non so che pensare. È vero che ci sono decine e decine di autori sotto contratto e tantissime pubblicazioni contemporanee, ma chi ha dato il via libera a questa storia, si dovrebbe solo vergognare. Speriamo che questa protesta legittima arrivi ai piani alti…

(l'autore retwitta solo le cose positive?sai che novità…)
